Expectation1: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation1: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story:
I stood in the workshop, the scent of sawdust thick in the air, my hands running over the handles of my tools. The checklist for safety inspections was taped to the wall, a daily ritual before any structural work began. I knew how important it was—one missed crack in a hammer handle, one dull blade, and someone could get hurt. My crew depended on me to keep the site safe, and I took that responsibility seriously.

But my phone buzzed with a reminder: the online candidate forum for our district was starting. I’d promised myself I’d be more involved this year, to listen, to ask questions, to vote with real knowledge. The city was changing fast, and I wanted my voice to count. I could hear the candidates’ voices through the phone, already debating issues that mattered to me.

I glanced at the tools, then at my phone, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in. The expectation to keep my team safe clashed with my duty as a citizen to stay informed and engaged. My heart pounded as I stood there, torn between the workshop and the world outside, knowing I couldn’t give both my full attention at once.
